poem:
Threads of Body and Soul

In a chaos of crimson we tangle,
needle-eye, nipple, silent lips;
an obnoxious ballet of agony and pleasure.
Our hair, detritus in the drain,
yet cherished in a locket's embrace —
A paradox of our human existence.
As the needle pierces,
we are both flaw and keepsake,
both abject and adored,
a mess of blood and sentiment.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Unravel review – a gorgeously excessive tangled knot of a show, full of blood, pain and pleasure A needle piercing an eye, the image sewn with human hair. Another needle through a nipple and a third sewing up the lips to silence them. Detached from the body, human hair can be waste – there’s something abject and awful about hair clogging a sink – and it can be a sentimental keepsake kept in a locket.". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
